content.description: Start just to the left of the mossy edge of the arete.   Climb up passing 2 horizontal cracks to reach a nice stance at the base of a short and dirty slab.  Get gear just below the slab, it's the last pro before the top.   Top it out.
content.location: This is the first route you will come to on the Lickmaster Block from the approach trail.

content.description: Crux is the middle between the two rails. Can be set as a TR after you climb up Way up
content.protection: Two well placed bolts at the top; recently placed within the last couple of years or so. Looks like there is places for pro,  but Im not pro enough to try it.

content.location: The arete left of the tree

content.description: Thin flakes just right of tree
content.location: Thin flakes just right of tree

content.description:
This crack has not yet seen a clean ascent, however it will go and can be done so on traditional pro.  It's likely 5.12, and on the high side of the grade.  Start at the base of the crack and undercling up to reach a variety of flared hands and finger locks.   Reach the obvious bottle neck slot and follow the flared crack until it tapers.   From here, find horizontals to the top.    

  Beware, the large rock overhanging this route is not attached.  Do not pull on it!
content.location: Continue through the corridor between the Mungo Jelly Block and the Lickmaster Block.  Turn the corner on the Lickmaster block and look for the rotten tree at the base of an overhanging crack.

content.description: Start at angled letterbox jug, straight up

The Lickmaster Block has some really nice overhanging face climbs and stout crack project.   

  Note:  As of 8/2010, the standard rappel tree at the edge of the main face is looking pretty suspect.   The bolt anchors on top have not yet been replaced and although they appear solid, they are quite old.   To get off this block, there are many trees that can be slung about 10-15 feet back from the edge.
